thread.title: What's on this weekend

author: Telegraph Travel
title: What's on this weekend
text: Weekend weather forecast The country's weekend weather is currently predicted to be mainly sunny with a few clouds, and temperatures ranging from as low as 18°C in Aberdeen and Edinburgh to as high as 25°C in London tomorrow. On Sunday, rain is expected in parts of the north while the south remain dry, with temperatures again peaking at 25°C in the capital. 1. London Korean Festival The free music, dance and food extravaganza held at Trafalgar Square this Sunday aims to celebrate all things Korean in the capital. Visitors can expect live shows from f (x), said to be one of South Korea’s leading K-pop girl groups, a break dance battle featuring the country’s world champion b-boy group, Jinjo Crew, as well as a range of traditional Korean music and dance performances. Other highlights include cooking demonstrations from the Food Network’s celebrity chef Judy Joo and various stalls showcasing London ’s best Korean cuisine. Korean food enthusiasts may also want to try a new Korean-inspired menu which launched this week at the Michelin-starred Galvin at Windows restaurant at the top of the Hilton on Park Lane, where the restaurant's South Korean head chef Joo Won marries traditional Korean flavours and ingredients with classic French cuisine. london.korean-culture.org Soo Kim Traditional Korean dance performers in London in 2012 Photo: Alamy 2. Gladiator Games Ambitiously, the Museum of London this week brings gladiators back to the site of London’s only Roman amphitheatre, found at the Guildhall in the City. It was here that gladiators fought 2,000 years ago, and in a somewhat less brutal re-enactment of those devastating battles, fighters will gather to prove their physical supremacy and secure their future. These Gladiator Games promise to be quite a spectacle but there’s more in store throughout the event. As well as watching the combat, the audience can participate in less rabid pursuits. Roman pottery classes, music lessons and cookery sessions are all on offer, while there’ll also be a chance to tour Roman ruins and explore the streets of Londinium. John O'Ceallaigh • The best things to do in London this weekend See the battle commence at the Gladiator Games 3. The London Triathlon See the capital’s toughest athletes battle it out at the annual event, with individual distance levels ranging from a 400m swim, a 10km bike journey and a 2.5km run to a 1.5km swim, 80km bike race and 10km run. thelondontriathlon.com 4. Wilderness Festival With wild swimming in a wooded lake, natural saunas, vintage stalls and even camel rides, Wilderness was the first major UK festival to shift the focus from its music bill to a more holistic idea of fun, involving crafts, theatre, forest raves and good food. Lavish banquets along long wooden tables sell out each year, with dishes from chefs Angela Hartnett and Raymond Blanc. There is a cookery school too, along with a debating forum, a fiction tent and yoga masterclasses. Not that the music is to be sniffed at. This year sees Bjork, Perfume Genius and Hercules & Love Affair down at the pretty Oxfordshire estate. Tickets for a full weekend’s camping are £187.62. wildernessfestival.com • Britain's weirdest festivals Natalie Paris A dance session at the Wilderness Festival in 2012 Photo: Alamy 5. Edinburgh Fringe A series of festivals kicks off in Edinburgh from today, including Edinburgh Fringe ( edfringe.com ). The biggest arts event in the world takes over the city for three weeks of entertaining and often indescribable mayhem. The Edinburgh International Festival ( eif.co.uk ) features the original and best theatre, classical music, opera, dance and art from around the world, while the Edinburgh Foodies Festival ( foodfestival.com ) is a celebration of feasting, with street food, a producers’ market, pop-up restaurants, live entertainment and instruction from top Scottish chefs. Linda Macdonald, Telegraph Travel’s Edinburgh expert 6. Cowes Week Aberdeen Asset Management Cowes Week is the season’s most laid-back event, with sails billowing gloriously on the Solent. This sailing regatta takes place over a week in the demanding five-mile-wide channel between the Isle of Wight and the south coast of England. The partying happens afloat and on shore. Cowes has really got its act together ashore, including huge screens live-streaming the racing action and loads of music, bars and activities for all ages. The fireworks are a must-see: they take place at 9.30pm on the harbour on the last Friday, after an RAF Typhoon fly-past. Sophie Campbell, Telegraph Travel's London expert • The best Isle of Wight hotels Cowes Week 2015 Photo: Getty Images 7. Bristol International Balloon Fiesta In its 37th year, the annual hot air balloon festival is Europe's largest, attracting nearly 500,000 participants and more than 100 hot air balloons flown each year. The event continues this weekend with some of its quirkiest balloon designs yet including the Minion character seen in the film Minions, as well as a Satzenbrau beer bottle, a Panasonic battery and the Scottish Cup trophy. bristolballoonfiesta.co.uk • Bristol: a cultural city guide SK The 2015 Bristol International Balloon Fiesta Photo: Getty Images 8. Fantastic Four The American sci-fi film based on Marvel Comics’ longest-serving superhero team of the same name opened across UK cinemas yesterday with critical reviews. While the film might feel “grindingly dour” with an “infectious” gloom, you have to “at least admire its attempt to introduce a few new flavours into the ice-cream stall”, describes the Telegraph’s film critic Robbie Collin . A scene from the new Fantastic Four film Photo: Fantastic Four • Fantastic Four: film review • Fantastic Four trailer 9. Battle anniversaries Marking this year’s 600th anniversary of the Battle of Agincourt, Hampshire’s Portchester Castle will host a re-enactment of the army preparing to set sail for France, featuring displays of military skills, archery and football tournaments plus live music, children’s activities and historical vendors. For more battle celebrations, head to Worcestershire for the Battle of Evesham Festival marking the 750th anniversary of the battle between Simon de Montfort and Prince Edward II in the Baron War. Guests can enjoy live battle re-enactments, archery and falconry displays as well as tours and treasure trails. english-heritage.org.uk visitworcestershire.org SK 10. Blackpool Air Show Marking it’s 106th year, the annual air show at Blackpool Pleasure Beach will feature a performance by the RAF Red Arrows over the promenade, daring wing walkers, a host of other air displays as well as music and entertainment throughout the weekend. visitblackpool.com SK The Blackpool Pleasure Beach promenade Photo: Getty Images The best of the rest Also worth a visit might be the Tequila and Mezcal Fest in Liverpool which is hosting the second instalment of what is said to be Britain’s first festival of its kind celebrating the music, food and culture of Mexico. The event features live music from a Mariachi band, cocktail master classes, a selection of tequila, mezcal and Mexican cuisine to sample, a Mexican art exhibition and more. • The renaissance of Liverpool Chilli Fiesta , one of Britain’s largest chilli festivals, returns to West Sussex for its 20th edition, featuring cooking demonstrations and a chilli throwing contest for kids, as well as live music, entertainment and a fireworks display. Red chillis Photo: Fotolia/AP Broadstairs Folk Week , the family-friendly folk music festival spread across various venues throughout the coastal town in Kent, has around 70 free events on offer including live music from a range of artists, music workshops, a youth camp for young musicians, a craft fair and dance procession through the town.
